Revised indicators for period 2016-2019 1. At least one policy review document adopted until the end of the project duration. 2. Updated Biomass related REAP of BiH and adopted for use in practice until January 2018. 3. Identification, quantification and mapping of biomass exploitation in BiH developed until December 2018 4. Forest governance mechanisms developed to support best practices (forestry practices, BAT and operational methods) and recommendations to increase utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. At least three RES infrastructure projects implemented until the end of 2018, at least another 6 RES infrastructure projects implemented based on newly developed financial schemes until 2020.
Indicators for period 2009-2015 1. no. of schools with biomass boilers totalling 5200 tCO2e in direct emissions reductions 2. no. of regions where business model has been replicated 3. amount of sustainably sourced biomass fuelwood supplied at competitive price 4. reduction of perceptions of fuel supply risk based on consumer confidence survey 5. percentage increase in biomass energy awareness and capacity in project area

comment.narrative:
Revised baseline for 2016-2019 period: 1. No policy review documents related to wood biomass 2. REAP of BiH does not include specific wood biomass segments and targets 3. No exact data on biomass exploitation in BiH 4. No forest governance mechanisms in place to directly support utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. Zero infrastructure projects
Baseline for 2009-2015 period 1. (0) zero schools with biomass boilers 2. (0) zero regions where business model has been replicated 3. (0) no impact surveys on awareness, perceptions and capacity of biomass energy

1. 1. Platform Declaration signed by the BiH Presidency, setting the basis for organization of three Dialogue Platform Conference. Conferences have an evolving nature with topics from previous ones discussed further. To date, over 50 recommendations were made at the Conferences. 2. Target reached. In total, it is estimated that 1,138,084 persons or more than 30% of the population in Bosnia and Herzegovina were engaged via various Grant Facility, outreach, communications and advocacy activities. 3. Target reached. Analysis of January- April 2014 when compared to the same period in 2016 show a 309% increase. 2014: (jan-apr) = 226. 2016: (jan-apr) = 700 4. Target reached. 3 Conferences organized. Additional series of 4 regional and 1 joint youth forums organized, and capacity of NGOs and government officials (Youth Officers) from all levels developed. At the end of project these total to 18 Youth Forums gathering 500 youth from across the country. 5. Target reached. Nationwide youth network emerged from youth fora, grant applicants and dialogue platform. 7 Projects brought members from all parts of the country. Network members maintain contact via closed DFF Facebook group. 6. Perceptions of youth have not changed significantly from 2012 when looking at the general population survey. description.narrative: Assistance to Bosnia and Herzegovina in the preparation of its third National Communication (TNC) for the implementation of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change.

independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Third National Communication Report Preparation in Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: 1. TNC (Third National Communications) submitted to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) 2. - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory capacity for data collection and analysis process maintained and strengthened - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory for years 2001-2009 and 2012-2013 completed 3. - Strengthened Vulnerability and Adaptation (VA) Team - Updated and strengthened chapter on Vulnerability and Adaptation (VA) 4. - Updated and strengthened chapter on Mitigation - Registration of BiH National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMAs) enabled 5. - Updated account of National Circumstances prepared and capacity to collect and manage information strengthened - Technology Needs Assessment completed - TNC (Third National Communication) prepared, translated and edited, submitted and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1. BiH submitted its Second National Communication (SNC) to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) Secretariat in Nov 2013 2. - Inventory for the period 1990-2001 carried out by independent consultants - Inventory for 2010-2011 in progress - Not all emissions from energy, industrial and waste sectors covered - Several gases not measured - Need for revision of coal emission factors 3. - Set of environmental indicators not established in BiH - Lack of data on flood and draught - Discussion of vulnerability and impacts in the SNC (Second National Communications) is primarily qualitative in nature - No studies on climate change (CC) impact in tourism and health sectors 4. - Business as Usual scenario and two mitigation scenarios till 2025 developed under SNC (Second National Communications) project - No National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMA) approving authority established for BiH - No NAMA (National Appropriate Mitigation actions) created for BiH 5. - National Communication (NC) described in SNC (Second National Communications), but information on technology, finance and capacity needs, require further elaboration - No Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) undertaken in BiH

description.narrative: Project started in 2015. 1. Quality of water management in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment in order to identify weak points and appropriate measures for improvement. 2. Coordination between partners at local, state, entity, cantonal and local government levels enhanced through joint design of concrete initiatives for the Main Phase. 3. Quality of business friendly environment and economic conditions in relevant partner municipalities determined through assessment.

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. 2. Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. 3. Despite positive experiences, including pilot “business-friendly” certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

Project started in 2015. 1. Assessment of institutional, operational and financial capacities of water utilities in at least 25 selected local governments conducted, and possible measures defined. 2. Concrete initiatives for the Main Phase designed stemming from at least 6 coordination meetings between UNDP and representatives of relevant institutions on local, entity, and state level. 3. Assessment of business friendly environment in at least 25 selected local governments conducted. 4. Full fledged document for the Main Phase prepared.

1. Completed assessments of institutional, operational and financial capacities of water utilities in 31 selected local governments, and defined possible measures to be implemented in project Main phase. 2. Completed assessments of institutional, operational and financial capacities of 31 selected local governments, and defined possible measures to be implemented in project Main phase. 3. Held 6 coordination meetings between UNDP and representatives of relevant institutions on local, entity, and state level, which resulted in concrete initiatives and recommendations to be taken up in Main phase. 4. Assessment of business friendly environment conducted in 31 selected local governments. 5. Full fledged project document for the Main Phase copleted and approved.

1. Prepare draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens’ utility performance. Share with all 18 LGs and seek approval of PSA wording. 2. Initiate activities on addressing key regulatory gaps related to local service delivery in the environmental and economic sectors. 3. Develop methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Distribute results for each partner Local government and publish results, which will be used for baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities.

Main phase officially started in June 2016. 1. Prepared draft Public Service Agreements (PSAs) detailing roles and responsibilities in terms of water supply and wastewater management services in target localities, including concrete oversight by LG councils and citizens’ utility performance. Drafts shared with all 18 LGs for agreement on PSA wording and initiated preparations for adoption on LG level. 2. Initial assessment conducted and basic legal gaps identified and recommendations provided for both environmental and economic sectors, with input from all project stakeholders from public and private sectors. 3. Developed methodology and questionnaires for conducting an initial Citizen Satisfaction Survey in all 18 partner local governments. Completed surveys for 5,750 individual survey responses. Distributed and published results for each partner Local government. Established baseline on citizen satisfaction levels with local authorities as of 2016 year-end.

1. Performance Management System – prepare individual Annual Support Protocols (annual work plans for each of the partner LGs) for all 18 partner LGs. Agree baseline data and indicators for tracking improvements, and start implementation of jointly agreed activities with each partner LG on providing technical assistance aimed at improvements of public and internal services. 2. Methodology for Performance-based Financial Support to be presented to and agreed with all partner LGs, including an overview of baseline package and basic performance indicators. Activities leading towards financial support agreed with LGs; start working on improvements in performance indicators as per agreed plans. 3. Conduct legal assessment to establish current levels of compliance with regulatory and operational frameworks for disaster risk reduction (DRR) in two partner local governments – Doboj and Tuzla. Present reports to two LGs and agree next steps towards reducing recognized and associated risks. 4. Conduct a multi-sectoral assessment of value chains in all partner local governments, with recommendations for improvements and strengthening of identified value chains. 5. Design a framework of good local governance, including universal set of performance benchmarks, with a clear vision on the future municipal good governance framework. Create inputs for a feasible good governance pilot-model for Bosnia and Herzegovina, with piloting and some initial institutionalisation within 18 target localities. 6. Provide in-depth technical assistance to utilities in order to improve their staffing, technical and organizational structures. Design the 2nd cycle of technical assistance for 2017-2018 (organizational capacities) to water utility companies, to reflect gaps not addressed in the first cycle. 7. Support upgrading public utilities’ financial management capacity through developing needs assessments for project water utility companies, regarding necessary hardware and software solutions r

1.Select participating local communities and local governments and conduct baseline surveys, including citizen’s satisfaction survey. 2. Conduct Regional comparative review to identify successful institutional and legal frameworks for community governance to serve as platform for country-wide discussion on the future role of local communities in Bosnia and Herzegovina and possible regulatory changes.

1. Comprehensive questionnaire for the assessment and baseline of the local communities and local governments was designed and public call for expression of interest among 84 local governments has been launched. 2. Regional comparative review has been drafted.

1. At least 10 Municipalities and 60 MZs selected for participation in programme 2. At least 60 MZ engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH representing effectively around 90,000 citizens 3. 1 study visit organized for key stakeholders, with at least 40% female participants. 4. 750 social and economic stakeholders, socially excluded groups, and women engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH. 5. Analytical report on MZs, including comparative review of legal frameworks in BiH and other countries prepared and widely disseminated
6. 10 municipalities and at least 60 MZs are selected based on a set of criteria. 7. 60 MZs within target local governments effectively engaged in local policy design and delivery cycle. 8. 60 MZ leaders and staff who strengthen their organizational capacity and skills. 9. 2 tailored and interactive training programmes designed and delivered to target groups. 10. 600 CSO and MZ activists within target areas receive training or coaching, including at least 40% women and 10% representatives of socially excluded groups. 11. 1. 23 local governments (municipalities) and 125 MZs selected for program participation. 2. 84 local governments and 166 MZs engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH representing over 300,000 people. 3. 3 study visits organized, with over 150 participants with at least 40% female participation. 4. 750 social and economic stakeholders, including local governments, MZs, media, academia, most vulnerable, and women engaged in and contributed to the definition of a new vision for MZs in BiH. 5. Analytical report on MZs, including initial comparative review of legal framework in BiH and four other countries (Switzerland, Sweden, Croatia and Serbia) finalized and disseminated to over 1500 individuals across the country. 6. 23 local governments selected based on detailed set of criteria, careful review by selection committee and field visits. 7. 125 MZs within targeted local governments effectively engaged in local policy design and delivery cycle through attendance at over 204 forums across the 23 local governments. 8. Over seven rounds tailor made and interactive training programs designed and delivered in five different topics to 1500 individuals from target groups. 9. 1500 CSO and MZ activists within target areas received training and coaching, including at least 46% women and 10% socially excluded groups. 10. Basic operating conditions improved in 77 MZs.

1. Legal review including result impact assessment completed in relation to vision models created 2. Advocacy plan for potential changes in the local governance law created 3. At least 10 meetings with city’s council and MZ council implemented 8. Political barometer mechanism created and tested 9. At least 6 start-up meetings gathering 300 people from 23 LG representatives realized 10. Webplatform BETA version created and tested 11. At least two big Networking events organized gathering at least 23 LG partner organizations

independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Floods affected population of Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Increased sustainability and resilience of the flood affected population and institutions through targeted assistance in a number of vital recovery areas: 1500 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 100 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms

comment.narrative: The natural disaster affected a quarter of the territory approximately one million people and some 27% of the country's population of 3.8 million. Nearly 50%of municipalities were hit by the floods, 46 of which have suffered severe damage and destruction, where urban, industrial and rural areas were completely flooded with water, cut off and without electricity, drinkable water or communication for days. Some 50,000 homes have been damaged or flooded leading to evacuation of 40,000 persons and loss of over 15,000 persons.

203 households assisted with animal feed for early recovery 17 most affected health centers equipped with medical equipment and vehicles 76 households received greenhouses 7 public water utility companies restored their water and sanitation systems dairy value chain improved in the canton zenica-doboj through targeted assistance to affected households and reconstruction of milk collection points and farms 5 houses constructed

comment.narrative:
Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

Targets for Objective 1: 3,400 dwellings in flood-affected areas repaired (target value: 4,640). 11,900 vulnerable people within flood-affected areas returned home/resume life in normal living conditions Comprehensive National Risk Assessment surveys conducted
Targets for Objective 2: 47 educational institutions in affected areas rehabilitated and reequipped 4 flood-affected locations mitigated in terms of landslide and flood risk 10 rehabilitated public buildings with increased energy efficiency 45,000 children benefiting from rehabilitated and reequipped educational infrastructure in affected areas 3 municipal public administration facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved municipal administrative service delivery in flood-affected areas. 2 healthcare facilities in affected areas rehabilitated 210,000 citizens benefiting from restored/improved healthcare services in affected areas 1 social welfare facility in flood-affected areas rehabilitated 55,000 representatives of vulnerable groups in affected areas benefiting from restored/improved social services 4 child-friendly spaces constructed to ensure temporary learning and playing facilities for 2, 000 children in affected areas and number of children benefiting 74 local roads and infrastructure reconstructed 25 critical water and sanitation facilities in flood-affected areas reconstructed
Targets for objective 3: 3,686 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas 60 MSMEs supported to restore economic activity 100 commercial agriculture households linked into the local market value chain (grain producers, subsistence farmers, poultry farmers and raspberry producers)

Results for Objective 3 3,180 jobs in agriculture and local businesses retained or created in affected areas 60 MSMEs supported to restore economic activity 104 commercial agriculture households linked into the local market value chain (grain producers, subsistence farmers, poultry farmers and raspberry producers)

Vrbas river basin (12% of BiH territory) covered by an automated hydrometric monitoring network for effective Flood Forecasting and Early Warning. 3. Policy environment and regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer established or strengthened 4. Strengthened Capacity to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies 5. Number of institutions enabled to modify risk management strategies based on introduced vulnerability, loss and damages assessment and improved hydrometric monitoring technologies 6. Number of people in target basin benefiting from flood risk management adaptation technologies, tools, and adaptation strategies, and are less exposed to flood risk 7. Availability of innovative non-structural measures introduced and implemented as part of climate adaptation strategies to provide improved resilience to communities (include agric. 8. Number of communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. 0 strategic flood risk management technologies in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. No automatized and centralized hydrometric network in Vrbas river basin 3. No policy/regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer in place 4. Local professionals are unaware of adaptation technologies 5. Most of the socio-economic information required to assess flood damages, losses, exposure and vulnerability is not currently available and is not collected systematically and gender-disaggregation of data not systematically done. 6.Current approach limited of inclusion of local communities, and particularly the vulnerable groups 7.Current approach to flood risk management is structural flood protection measures and non-structural measures are not considered to be adaptive measure. 8. 0 communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding.

Project started in 2015
1. Establish inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management 2. Rehabilitate hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin 3. Complete modeling on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin 4. Develop spatial data infrastructure for Vrbas River Basin

1. Inter-agency working group on climate changes and flood risk management consisting of representatives of water agencies, hydro-meteorological institutes and geodetic institutes established. 2. Hydro-metric network in Vrbas River Basin, consisting of 28 gauges, established. 3. Models on climate change impact in Vrbas River Basin developed. 4. Spatial data infrastructure, including geoportal, for Vrbas River Basin established.

1. Complete topographic (LiDAR) survey for flood risk area in Vrbas River Basin. 2. Develop methodology for flood hazard ans risk mapping in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. Complete hydrological modelling of Vrbas River Basin. 4. Initiate development of the National Adaptation Plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina. 5. Create institutional set-up for flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

1. LiDAR survey completed. 2. Methodology for flood hazard and flood risk mapping finalized and adopted by local authorities. 3. Hydrological model for Vrbas River Basin, which integrates climate change models, completed. 4. UNFCCC focal point request for UNDP assistance in developing National Adaptation Plan received. 5. Analysis of institutional responsibilities in flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina completed and proposal for set-up in Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted to relevant institutions.

description.narrative: The high hazardous munitions and complex weapons systems are disposed of. The pace of ammunition destruction is increased. Capacities of the Ministry of Defense and Armed Forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina are improved and selected ammunition storage facilities are upgraded to be aligned with the international standards.

comment.narrative: There are 17,000 tonnes of ammunition surpluses that require urgent disposal. The capacities of the Ministry of Defense of Bosnia and Herzegovina for ammunition stockpile management are weak. The capacities for those interventions must be improved. The safety standards of storage facilities are to aligned with the international standards.

1. Disposal of 3,000 tonnes of ammunition, out of which 751 tonnes under EXPLODE and EXPLODE+ outputs. 2. Conducted six training session (four Special Events, and two trainings for Explosive waste incinerator for 10 AF BiH members, and firefighting exercise at five locations: Krupa - Hadzici, Kula- Mrkonjic Grad, Rabic - Dervetna, TBT - Visoko, and TROM Doboj). 3. Finalized 50% of infrastructure upgrades on 51 ammunition depot. (Krupa - Hadzici, Kula- Mrkonjic Grad, Rabic - Dervetna, TBT - Visoko, and TROM Doboj).

1. Contributiot to disposal of 2,300 tonnes of ammunition. 2. Conduct five workshops on ammunition disposal and management 3. Planning session for MOD and AF BIH Operations with ammunition and explosive ordnance for 2018
